text: so we run our sprints as experiments so we generally do weekly sprints and we run them sort of based on this
hypothesis that the entire team comes up with on at the beginning of the iteration and
the reason we do it is that what we want to do is ensure that every week we're continuously deploying software
but we want to sort of anchor our iterations in a user testing session and we want to ensure we know what we're testing and we
want to ensure that we know sort of what analytics are coming back from that test and we use that to inform the next
week's experiment and all of this is sort of to the point of we want to pay down risk in a project
and oftentimes that's technical risk oftentimes it's actually the product risk so i think the thing to be aware of is
we're not just thinking about development anymore we're thinking about sort of how things are going to be used by people and ensuring that
what we're developing is sustainable but it's also going to be usable so you don't get a lot of craft in your in your code because you're
constantly sort of refactoring and aiming towards reducing risk in your project
so what we end up doing is we have lots of conversations about stories i think it's really important to sort of point
out that stories that are understood by the whole team that are actionable are incredibly important so when i say get the story
straight having the conversations with your team about what is risky how you can mitigate that risk how you
can design that risk out entirely and then what's sort of the easiest first pass of a story versus
kind of the bigger thing these are the the types of conversations that can both get your team to communicate better with one another and
also honestly get to a product faster so the other thing we do which is actually really fun endeavors you've got
a bunch of these stories that have come out you can talk them through kind of through this like hipster cross cross up on the wall and we're trying to
figure out what's the biggest bang for the buck right so the product owner has the opportunity to take these stories
and they put them up on the vertical axis so highest priority at the top lowest priority at the bottom and they're really the voice of the product
and the customer at this point in time what do they feel like is the utmost importance for them for this
project and then both the developers and designers get to come in and take those feature stories and move them on
horizontal axis the designer might say you know assistant take two or three flows it's going to be actually quite a bit of work
for us to sort of solve this problem that's a lot of work or they can say you know this is a really quick hit developers get the same voice right they
get to be like well i actually see an easy way for us to do this feature it's going to be you know load locks so at the end you sort of end
up with this biggest bang for the lowest box scenario and what you're trying to do is grab together a set of features that is going
to get you to a deliverable hole so this is something that as you can imagine being a consultancy but honestly
for any organization if you as a development team and really a product team can step away at any
point have a cohesive piece of software that is usable by customers you've done your job you
know you're not confusing people you're not dropping out a bunch of features that are sort of disparate you're delivering the whole user
experience and so what we're trying to do is ideally every friday these sprints that we're doing we can step away and there is working
software that has business value to the customers so always sort of aiming to the deliverable whole is something that
we're trying to do with our teams and then the other thing this question constantly comes up really
and it's where does design fit in and this is kind of the crux of agile a lot of designers are like i'm not going to be working at the pace that
these developers are working at what we try to do is what we call just in time design so there's two reasons we
do this one is that designers are always going to need to sort of have a big picture scenario and we're not trying to rush them
through that process but what we can do is we can empower developers with things like you know you can
imagine bootstrap there's a ton of different frameworks at this point in time where you can get a product out
to where you can test it with just enough design to where you're finding that product market fit you know what you recognize
when you're doing product development is that the actual brand experience is going to change over time when you're
sort of fine tuning what people want from this application so what we're looking to do is have just
enough design to get us to the point where we can really validate or refute our hypothesis about what it's useful
and then we can step back and oftentimes midway through the project that's when we do a design spike and that's when the
designers really have a much better understanding of how people are using the product what they want out of it what really the visual voice should be
at that point so what we're trying to do is really empower the developers with design tools through
you know visual style guides and you know using sort of frameworks that exist so that they can sort of continue development
without feeling like they're putting pressure on designers and that they're not blocked by the sun the other thing we're doing this is just
really a fun one is at the very beginning of a project everyone has in their own mind their own perception of
what they perceive as a project risk and a lot of the time you'll watch like the development team like run off through the corner man i
think this is a totally stupid idea of what they're thinking yeah yeah and they see risk in the project that's very different than the designers
and the product owner so what we like to do at the beginning of a project is sort of get everyone on the same page
put a bunch of big question cards up on the wall and say what do you think is the scariest part about this project what do you think is your biggest
question what do you think is the biggest risk and people sort of you know go in isolation they write down all these cards and you put it up on the
wall and these stay on the wall for the duration of the project and it really sort of alleviates that sort of like
infighting that can happen and it also allows everyone to be really empathetic about what others like perceived risks are and their fears
are so it's actually kind of a really powerful dynamic to get everyone in line okay so i want to jump into some case
studies um so these are two clients that we worked with that were just really amazing and actually on
these projects it really helped fine tune our approach to integrating agile
and being ux so book runner is a company that has a really amazing sort of
objective they are trying to make education more affordable for students by having the purchase of textbooks to be much
more transparent in terms of the pricing structure so what they were trying to do was get to a place where
they could put that information in front of students when and where they needed it which is effectively at the university bookstore
when the students are sitting there with their class syllabus so what we're trying to do is a mobile solution using
sms and mobile webkit because a lot of these kids don't have flip phones and then additionally trying to figure
out what the best way was for them to really understand that they have a lot of different options for purchasing textbooks so really
amazing engagement really amazing product that came out of it second is um there's a company called share
through and what they're doing is they have a platform for native thread advertising being embedded
into their um embedded into brand content and tracking that is sort of where they can
service analytics to marketing departments to understand really where their brand videos
are becoming where they're being viewed and when they kind of go viral so what we wanted to do was
take all of this data they were gaining from you know the distribution of these videos and way you know huge far sort of nested
domains and figure out where the video went when it was viewed and really at what point
did it get really popular and go viral and really who was the influencer that did that so you can imagine it was really
powerful for marketers because they could sort of have this one snapshot of where the distribution and
what channels it was google plus it was facebook if it was shared through where their video really became powerful

and specifying what it is that we're going to do with the developers and the designers and then wednesday that's what we're
building and refining so we're actually decoding we're designing and then friday this is when we get our customer feedback
the one thing i will say is that we look to have a flexible schedule so
something that happens during the course of this project is maybe you have more meetings in on mondays at the beginning of a

often enough to where people feel very easy to say let's table this for later we know what we're doing let's have this
conversation so this is just sort of a note that these schedules are flexible and even
though we anchor it with kicking off the iteration planning on mondays with the friday user testing what we're
looking to do is we're maximizing efficiency here minimizing the amount of sort of documentation that needs to happen
and trying to facilitate any conversations between these different groups of people as often as possible so
mondays we do our user tests on friday so monday is really after the week you've had some time to reflect you come in this is where
we kind of allow the team to do a little bit of wide thinking and this is the time when design can get
involved and based on what they saw the user doing we can run design shorts does anyone

how many designers do we have in the audience i think

can push technology and that can inform design so we would absolutely have the developers
in through this sort of like broad thinking and ideating on how we could pivot on a product um particularly if we were doing stuff

again i want to emphasize we bring the whole team in on this so this is the product learning the designers the developers
at the same time running a retrospective so they're doing the i like i wish i wills with one another and then
we're clustering those to sort of come to learnings about how we can all work better together and what we want to carry forward
the other thing we do is that when we do our user testing we're ensuring that we're capturing feedback so we actually have um an application

see people writing and moving the notes around so if you have distributed teams this is really helpful and what we do though is that this is
sort of a living document that allows us to keep track of what's happening for user tests and it allows us to sort of do clustering exercises about
shared observations of what the users are doing with the application so we kind of go over this and this inevitably leads to a lot of ideas being
generated have a whiteboard ready this is where the product people this is actually the product of our book runner jumping up
with an idea about how he wanted to see the two different flows because we were supporting sms and mobile webkit how we needed to
sort of have those two flows happen based on some feedback that we've gotten from users on friday so
he's not a designer but he's jumping up and he's sort of informing the designer with some thoughts that he had based on
what he needs and the users do these are really easy ways without creating a ton of documentation and
delivering it to your team that you're having those conversations real time and it minimizes the amount of time that's on one
individual person and on another individual person to understand what's been given to them
so the final thing that we do really on our monday iteration kickoff meetings is that we do our hypothesis definition
so this is something that can come out of just straight discussion and it's you know also something that the entire team gets
to agree upon so obviously the product owner is the one that gets to drive the hypothesis
but what you find is that the whole team has really been having these conversations and so the agreement sort of comes together
pretty fluidly and again this is where we're sort of trying to figure out what are the features that we need to develop
that are going to give us that cohesive whole a hypothesis that we can test that friday
with users and what are we going to see is sort of the metric that will either refute or validate our
hypothesis so the other thing that i'd like to emphasize is on mondays we give our
teams some time to sort of pay down the technical debt so having a couple hours to do refactoring or do those things as
developers are like oh this part of the code is smelling a little bit i want to fill out some tests i want a factor i want to
also what ends up happening is as you're sort of pivoting your product there's features that are not going to get used anymore see if you can clean
this up keep your code really streamlined so you can continually add onto it that you're moving forward the same thing ends up happening a
little bit with design there's a lot of cleanup that happens and the funny thing that happens is when you have people witnessing
users using both code and the design that they've created they are so excited so motivated to fix
those things um so this is actually a really powerful thing to do on mondays so tuesdays we kind of got a little bit
broad on mondays this is when we really focus and get specific i will say this is when we're doing our
story writing but frankly story writing happens throughout the week because there there isn't really a time that this happens or a date that this happens
this happens all the time but what i will say is that there's definitely an art to story writing and a lot of it has to do with the
conversations that you want to have about stories um this looks like a ton
of stuff to writing for a story um what i will say is that what we try to do at the very beginning
of a project is sort of enforce some discipline around story writing by making it really lengthy to begin
what will end up happening over the course of the cycle of the team is that this will degrade a little bit
but even if it degrades a little bit your bar is still incredibly high so what we're looking to do with the stories here is a have that conversation
but we're facilitating the conversation with creating a narrative and the narrative is really identifying the persona that we're

the business value and then we're backing that up with a very clear acceptance criteria so this is
actually pulled from dan north's bdd so he's speaking at this conference which is really cool
here this helps us to sort of very quickly run through the scenarios both as

hey designer there's a much easier way we could do this you know this is going to be a one point story if we take this approach versus a

so the other thing that's going to end up happening at some point in your project is you're going to have a ton of stories so is anyone here familiar with story
mapping okay so this is actually a really effective way if you start to
label your stories with either the personas that you're kind of grading these stories for or sort of specific enough search or
account or you know labels that really specify what those stories are in sort of an epic context this will give you this

what it is that my development team is doing and it allows them to sort of go upwards in the company and say look this
is where the product is going this is what we're doing sort of this is how we're meeting the user needs um so we actually we wrote an application
called story mapper io for this if you use pivotal tracker and you use labels it literally will just suck it in

folks that are interested in sort of those like macro pictures so wednesday and thursday this is when

client is interested in it the other thing that sort of naturally happens at this point is that there is
an ability for team members to really be empathetic with one another and so they now can very quickly if they have

and we do a lot of this where it's a designer developer pairing together and they're actually looking at the code

you know let's get rid of this they're doing this in the code so they can just be checking in the css with html
whatever it is and they can deliver it real time with the designer right there no documentation necessary
no sort of waiting for anyone um so this is a really great way to keep the efficiencies running the other
thing that i'll say i think we all know this is like as personally us as developers we actually
like to get stories rejected mostly because it means that somebody is paying attention there is a critical eye being
put towards the work that we are delivering so i would say if anyone here is sort of doing acceptance for the team
definitely make sure you're doing this routinely it's the thing that sort of allows developers to know that someone's looking at the work that they're doing
and that it's being qa as well so this absolutely pays down risk that might be incurred
if no one is looking at these stories as they're being delivered so acceptance is really critical so finally friday this
is where we figure out how we do how we do it sorry so in the morning oftentimes it's sort of cleaning up the code doing
qa sort of integration testing and manually through the code and ensuring things are ready for the users that you're going to bring in this
afternoon so user testing is something that we try to make as lightweight as possible and as
continuous as possible during the course of our projects and the reason is is that if you can
dedicate you know your friday beer time to bringing in five users to test out your application
you're going to get such great feedback on what it is that you're producing to inform what you're doing the next week
the one thing to note is that plan this out so figure out sort of what is the narrative that you want to use to test out the
hypothesis that you've been working on that whole week so there's definitely a little bit of a trick to this and it's good to
do a little bit of research into what sort of the pitfalls all of you are of user testing and how to set up a
good user test but try to keep it as lightweight as possible otherwise it'll be too much of a headache for the team to really get
behind doing it so for us we um we actually wanted to create sort of a physical space because
we wanted to test how students were interacting with shelf tags in a virtual bookstore
so we actually used the book runner offices and we would bring in users to test we called it five on friday
and we did it in the offices so the developers were kind of like hanging around and they were able to witness users without making them feel sort of
awkward and we would put up these kind of you know fake bookshelves and we would allow them to use their flip thumbs whatever
it is they brought we you know bring them in and say here's like a 30 to 50 starbucks gift certificate or amazon
gift certificate and they actually had a lot of fun with it and so we got to watch exactly how they were interacting
with the tags how they were interacting with the program what the user flows were like where they were getting stuck um and we
would just sort of listen to them and let them run through the narrative and we would be taking notes the other thing that ended up happening
on the nibbly project was it's actually incredibly easy to get five students in on a friday it is incredibly hard to get kind of
marketing departments in to test out your application on friday much less five of them so what we ended
up doing is get as many as you can and keep it as lightly as you can as quick as you can but if you do get
someone of that caliber into your office you want to make use of that time as best as you can so with the nibbly
project because the data visualization that we were doing had so much animation and interactivity
to it we wanted to ensure that we were able to test with this person as much as we could in that one segment
so we would run our hypothesis at first and they were able to sort of see the visual language of the
interface that we had created in code and then we would abstract that out onto
a whiteboard mostly we did this because it ended up being really tricky to get people to sort of
immediately understand all of the data that was backing this interface and we wanted to sort of rev on that to
ensure that they were gaining understanding very quickly so we would throw up sort of the icons
the domain language that we had used in this interface and we would put it up on a whiteboard and we would start to draw lines and we basically create
a second test for them right then and there it's almost like a paper prototype but fueled by their understanding of
what those interactions were like and we could get two or three more tests out of them so that we could really steer our development the next week
without having to create a bunch of code to do that second test so this saved us literally like two or three weeks of
iteration time because we were able to have the markers then in there should we go through a secondary scenario
so the other thing just wanted to reiterate make sure you're capturing your feedback somewhere particularly if all of the
